Cazes attorney, Roger Bonakdar, immediately doubted the story that his client had killed himself, and he told Rabenn as much. Over the months that followed, he requested the video footage of Cazes' cell at the time of his death. He received neither. 13/14 https://t.co/JywsaYcDCd

When Sanchez arrived at Cazes' cell, it appeared to be empty, but Thai officers were peering over the cell's internal 3-foot wall. She walked in and looked down: Cazes' body, hidden behind that wall, was sprawled across the cell's bathroom area. 12/14 https://t.co/f5NOjezskY

During one late-night visit, this one on July 11, six days after his arrest, Cazes told Sanchez that he planned to escape‚Äîthat a helicopter gunship was coming to break him out. Sanchez brushed it off as a joke. Then, the next day, the unthinkable happened. 11/14 https://t.co/8Kui14n4iz

One DEA agent, Jen Sanchez was given the job of speaking with Cazes and persuading him to agree to extradition. She didn‚Äôt have the authority to offer much to Cazes in exchange for his cooperation. But she tried to show him kindness, to help him keep his spirits up. 10/14

Following his arrest, Cazes was taken to a Thai police building, where prosecutors hoped to persuade him to sign an extradition agreement, allowing them to deport him from Bangkok without a lengthy legal battle‚Äîand more ambitiously, to make him an informant. 9/14

Finally an agent nicknamed M broke free of the melee. His make-or-break assignment had arrived. He raced into the house, up the stairs, and into Cazes‚Äô bedroom. There it was, on a cheap white desk: Cazes' laptop. It was open. 8/14 https://t.co/Xl6fDdUotp

Cazes spun around, now in fight-or-flight mode, desperate to get back inside to his laptop. But one Thai officer and then another suddenly appeared, grabbing Cazes and wrestling him to the ground. 7/14

For a few moments, Cazes tugged at the gate, trying to get it back on its rails. Then he saw that one of the undercover agents, who had been posing as an electrician, was now sprinting towards him and wearing a police vest. 6/14

The undercover agent behind the wheel, doggedly playing her part, shouted‚Äîas loudly as possible, trying to project so that Cazes could hear inside the house‚Äîthat she needed to pay for the damage. A few seconds later, the kingpin finally emerged out of the house. 5/14

Police signaled for undercover agents to launch their plan: Crashing a Toyota Camry into his gate in an effort to lure him away from his laptop. Seconds later, a loud clang rang out across the cul-de-sac, Cazes‚Äôs wife came out of the house to assess the situation. 4/14

But before the team in Lithuania could finish their work, they accidentally crashed the AlphaBay server. It was now only a matter of time before Cazes realized something was amiss. The moment he closed his laptop, triggering its encryption, the operation would be over. 3/14 https://t.co/17OIqywZ9K

In a war-room across the city, agents and prosecutors monitored video-feeds of the scene. At the center of the long table was a conference phone connected to both the Thai team on the ground and another team of agents in Lithuania, tasked with imaging the AlphaBay server. 2/14
